text.head:
Goodwife Horndall, circa 1646, Newport, Rhode Island
by Christopher A. Mosher, Shelton, Connecticut, 2021.

div.p: The FamilySearch web site has in its database four index entries that refer to an individual as “Goodwin_”, the wife of John Horndall. This article shows that these entries are incorrect, and should instead refer to “Goodwife”.

In the FamilySearch database “Rhode Island Births and Christenings”, there are index entries for the mother in each of two events, birth[1] and baptism[2], of Mary Horndoll in 1645. There are two additional index entries for birth[3] and baptism[4] of another child, also named Mary Horndoll, in 1647. In each of these four entries, the father is shown as “Jno” and the mother is shown as “Goodwin_”, that’s with an underscore character at the end of the name. The underscore may indicate that the end of the name is omitted or illegible.

All four index entries indicate they were extracted from the same FamilySearch microfilm, “Records of births, marriages, and deaths of the Friends Meeting at Newport, R.I.”, which is available to the public on-line.[5] The film contains 143 facsimile images of a set of manuscript pages. The pages are approximately 7x9 inches, although the size cannot be determined accurately just by looking at the microfilm. The pages appear to be written on one side only. They all appear to be in the same handwriting, and written at approximately the same time. As indicated on the first page, they are a transcript from some original documents, described as “Friends meeting” records at Newport, Rhode Island. The handwriting is cursive, and very sloppy, with letters being omitted and merged together. There are many abbreviations. The transcription’s pages are sporadically numbered, with some pages having no numbers, and many cases of two subsequent pages having the same number.

The transcript may be in the same sequence as the original, because some of the page numbers from the original document are shown. These original page numbers are referred to in the following overview of the arrangement of the entire set of pages:
1. Births: surname index, followed by pp. 1-34 of entries
2. Marriages: surname index, followed by pp. 1-26 of entries
3. Deaths: surname index, followed by pp. 1-20 of entries
The entries themselves are in somewhat chronological order, but not consistently so.

The first page[6] of this set of manuscripts has a descriptive title, along with some references this is a copy of some other original item:
Records of Births, Marriages,
and deaths of the Friends
meeting at Newport R.I.
Loaned me by J E Woolley the original to
take home and return next day before
5 P.M. The book cost him $5 00. to have to
copy. He never loaned it before -
I was living in Lex Arr - His grand
mother was Catrin Cook - He gave the
book when he died to Shrewsbury Library.
Quaker
[page is stamped as follows:]
NEW YORK GENEALOGICAL AND BIOGRAPHICAL SOCIETY
DEC 7 1934
In first section, “Births”, the manuscript page numbered “12”[7] contains the two entries referred to by the FamilySearch database entries.

There are two entries for daughters named “Mary Horndall”:
Mary Horndall d[aughter of] Jno & Goodwife 1645
Mary Horndall d[aughter of] Jno & Goodwi 6-5-1647
This most likely indicates the elder Mary died sometime before the second Mary was born, say circa 1646. There are no other births of “Horndall” (or any similar surname) children shown in the manuscript.
One observation is that, although the index entries spell the surname as “Horndoll”, a more accurate reading is “Horndall”.

In way of a detailed analysis of these entries, for the first entry after the name of the child, “Mary Horndall”, is a “d” which presumably means “daughter”, since the document does contains entries with masculine names and “s”, for “son”. This is followed by “Jno” which is a traditional abbreviation for “John”. After the ampersand, “&”, is the name of the mother. As seen by examining other entries in this document, this position within the birth entries is reserved for the mother’s given name. It is never her maiden name, or other surname. In this particular case, the name is given as “Goodwife”, which (along with the short form Goody) is a traditional Puritan form of address for a respected wife.[8] The “f” is clearly indicated by its descender extending below the base line, and the ascender extending up to the same height as the ascender of the “d” earlier in the word. The entry for the second “Mary Horndall” is very similar, with what appears to be the same parents, although the mother’s given name is written only as “Goodwi” with the ending of the name being almost illegible. This illegible section may correspond to the underscore in the “Goodwin_” index extracts.
It would be highly unlikely for there to be two different couples, “John Hordall and Goodwife” and “John Hordall and Goodwi” in the local area within two years of each other, so we can safely assume these two entries refer to the same parents. Furthermore, it’s likely the transcriber omitted the ending “fe” from “Goodwife”, rather than the alternative of adding an “fe” to the end of “Goodwi”. Also, compare the “n” in Horndall to the ending of each of the mother’s names. The characteristic “n” shape, with a horizontal curved segment at the midline level, does not exist at the endings of either of the entries of the mother’s name.

This is not the surname “Goodwin”, as the index entries claim, based on two key pieces of evidence present in the original manuscript:
1. it’s in a position where it would be the given name of the mother, never the surname standing alone; and,
2. the descender of the lower case “f” is prominent, especially in the first entry, and could not possibly be an “n”, which would have no descender.
Rather, this is the title “Goodwife” applied to the wife of John Horndall, with her actual name left unspecified.
